title.text: Joint Apposition Extraction with Syntactic and Semantic Constraints

abstractContent.text: Appositions are adjacent NPs used to add information to a discourse.
We propose systems exploiting syntactic and semantic constraints to extract appositions from OntoNotes.
Our joint log-linear model outperforms the state-of-the-art Favre and Hakkani-Tür (2009) model by ∼10% on Broadcast News, and achieves 54.3% F-score on multiple genres.

introductionContent.text: Appositions are typically adjacent coreferent noun phrases (NP) that often add information about named entities (NEs).
The apposition in consists of three comma-separated NPs -the first NP (HEAD) names an entity and the others (ATTRs) supply age and profession attributes.
Attributes can be difficult to identify despite characteristic punctuation cues, as punctuation plays many roles and attributes may have rich substructure.
While linguists have studied apposition in detail, most apposition extraction has been within other tasks, such as coreference resolution) and textual entailment.
Extraction has rarely been intrinsically evaluated, with Favre and HakkaniTür's work a notable exception.
We analyze apposition distribution in OntoNotes 4 ( and compare rule-based, classification and parsing extraction systems.
Our best system uses a joint model to classify pairs of NPs with features that faithfully encode syntactic and semantic restrictions on appositions, using parse trees and WordNet synsets.
Our approach substantially outperforms Favre and Hakkani-Tür on Broadcast News (BN) at 54.9% F-score and has state-of-the-art performance 54.3% F-score across multiple genres.
Our results will immediately help the many systems that already use apposition extraction components, such as coreference resolution and IE.
